column1: Policy Jury on School-based clinics
column8: Eight 12-person juries were held around the state of Minnesota, one in each congressional district. The jurors were asked to evaluate the usefulness of school-based clinics to help prevent teen pregnancy, AIDS and other STDs. A statewide jury of 24 jurors made the final recommendations.
column9: Yes, the Steering Committee (composed of senators)
column26: A survey set up and conducted in all eight districts. 100 people randomly surveyed in each one. During this a quota sampling method was used, so that the jury pool matched the demographics of the district. Each 100 pool was divided into three attitudinal categories. Out of 800, 445 expressed a will to participate in a jury. Participants for each district randomly selected from the pools stratified based on attitudes towards proposed policy. Statewide jurors were voted by their peers.
column34: Act as witnesses to provide information and perspectives to the panel
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column46: In the final vote by the 96 jurors, 43% of them voted for the position which supported clinics, 7% voted for the position opposed, 50% voted for the position which favored alternatives.
column56: Difficulties were faced to maintain close relationship between the organizing staff and the steering committee of Senators
column57: It was interesting that in regional juries the votes were diverse - one jury voted in opposition to clinics, three voted for alternatives, and four voted in favor of clinics. Then a statewide jury was set up to produce a final opinion. The idea that school-based clinics should be used as major part of any new set of programs to prevent teen pregnancy etc. There was an initial 12-12 split on this question, after further discussion ended in 13-11.
column60: Commissioned by The Health and Human Services Committee of the Minnesota Senate, funded by Blandin Foundation

column1: Conference on drinking water
column8: Drinking water was put to the vote among 60 citizens, 60 experts and 60 politicians from the Folketinget (the parliament), regional and local authorities. At the conference, the 180 participants were deciding on five action plans for ensuring clean drinking water.
column26: Invited 1,020 randomly selected citizens aged 18-70, with 10 men and 10 women from each age group. The Central Population Register Agency of the Ministry of the Interior was charged with the random selection. This method means that the 1,020 people may be designated as a representative sample of the population. 150 citizens replied that they were interested in participating in the conference. 60 of them were selected for participation. The selection was performed by drawing lots, while still ensuring that participants were distributed as much as possible by age, sex and domicile.
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column45: Conference was followed by an opinion poll of the population. The population’s responses and the results from the Board conference were identical almost down to the last cipher.
column46: After deliberations the panel voted on the 5 proposed plans for the drinking water. The overall ballot result from citizens, experts and politicians elected the plan from the Danish Water Supply Association as winner, one vote over the plan of the Watershed Information Centre, which came second.
column60: Budget of The Danish Board of Technology

column1: Consensus conference: The Consumption and Environment of the Future
column7: Consensus conference: The Consumption and Environment of the Future
column8: To assess the means that should be employed to make consumption more sustainable.
column46: In the Final Document consumers point out that they are not encouraged, either culturally or economically, to buy environmental products and that this is one of the main barriers to sustainable consumption. Organic goods are for instance more expensive and harder to get. The consumer panel therefore recommends that an improved framework for environmentally sound ricing of goods should be provided through taxes and targeted support measures for environmental production. Both producers and consumers should experience being “green” as economically rewarding. And it should be easy regardless of place of residence and lifestyle. Consumers themselves bear some of the responsibility for a change in the pattern of consumption, but the consumer panel emphasizes that legislators are highly responsible for securing the framework for sustainable consumption.
column49: Specific response to participants about recommendations
column60: Budget of The Danish Board of Technology

column65: In November 1998, the Jury re-convened for one evening to examine selected pieces of the comprehensive plan that was developed by Dakota County, prior to final approval and acceptance by the County Board. For each of the issue areas about which the original Jury developed recommendations, county staff presented relevant parts of the comprehensive plan. The Jury then discussed that component of the Plan and, through a series of electronic voting procedures, told the county whether they felt the Jury's recommendations were accurately and appropriately reflected in the comprehensive plan.

column1: Consensus conference on radioactive waste management
column7: Consensus conference on radioactive waste management
column8: To focus on the effective and publicly acceptable long term management of nuclear waste in the UK, both civil and military, concentrating particularly on intermediate and high level waste
column26: Four thousand people, randomly selected from the national electoral register, were invited to take part in the consensus conference as a member of the citizens' panel. Just over 120 people responded expressing their interest. They were then contacted again, given details of the conference topic and asked to confirm that they were still available for the necessary dates. Around 70 people responded. From this group of people the 16 members of the panel were selected, essentially at random, whilst ensuring that there was an even balance of men and women with a mix of educational backgrounds and that regions throughout the country were represented.
column43: Learning sessions,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Participants can request information,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column46: In conclusion the panel was unanimous that in order for a solution to be publicly acceptable, the waste MUST remain accessible and monitorable to give future generations a chance to deal with the problem if/when a solution is found

Recruitment was carried out by the polling company Sonecom, which called 3,300 people in its contact database, 131 of whom showed interest in the project. In the end, 62 people were selected at random from these 131, according to age, gender, professional status. 
In some areas (a minority), the participants received a letter in advance with press articles from the launch press conference (with the 2 ministers commissioning the panel), what made the recruitement easier.
column34: Public officials (representatives from the 2 Ministerial cabinets and relevant regional public administrations): commissioning the citizens panel + general oversight in line with the subsidies; public independant institution (Maison de l'Urbanisme): help with identifying a varied and balanced group of resource persons on the theme, help with logistics; Academics and foreign experienced practitioner: help and oversight regarding each stage of the process (selection, hearing, deliberation).
column37: Outreach was ensured through: Press conference at the launch. Public event for the disclosure of the citizens report. Media coverage. Dissemination of results and later of a vade-mecum to a variety of stakeholders.
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Participants can request information,Learning sessions
column45: There was an opening event, partly open to the media, partly reserved to the panelists. There were interactions between panelist citizens and Maison de l'Urbanisme (among others) to help select resource persons. Written surveys were filled by participants once a day and used to steer the process.
column46: Final citizen report communicated to the 2 commissioning ministers as well as to other members of the Walloon government. Video of the process. Vade-mecum detailing the process.
column47: Final citizen report. It was communicated to the 2 commissioning ministers as well as to other members of the Walloon government (+ Video of the process. + Vade-mecum detailing the process)
column52: The implementation was not monitored, especially so as the main driver of the citizens panel, the scheduled change of policy in land use planning in the Walloon region (the 'révision des plans de secteurs'), was completely cancelled by the public authorities and never took place (even as of 2021).
column54: Participant exit survey,Process reflection by the organisers,Participant feedback session
column56: The challenges are described in the vade-mecum, not enough space here. Here are some more details on each evaluation method: 1) Participant exit survey: Anonymous evaluation forms were filled by citizen participants once a day on multiple questions (assessing how they felt, the quality of information brought to them, several questions on the work in small groups, the planning of each day). Every morning, a moderator synthetised the evaluations and signaled how organisers, resource persons and panelist citizens could take key elements from the evaluations into account. In the end, questions were also asked on how the panel possibly modified participants' views on the themes of the panel, and on their interest about participation in public decision-making. As it was the first citizens' jury/panel in Belgium (first citizens' deliberation based on randomly selected citizens, getting access to a balanced panel of stakeholders and experts), a developmental evaluation modus was decided ('ongoing' evaluation that steers social innovation processes in real time). The resource persons (experts, stakeholders bringing information to the panelists also took part to the evaluation through exit surveys, although with different questions. 2) Process reflexion by the organisers: A detailed 'vade-mecum' on the whole initiative and process was made public, to help organise similar initiatives in the future. 3) Participant feedback session: On 7 December 2001, more than 6 months after delivering their citizen report, panelist citizens came back together to review the initiative.
column57: Lessons learned from the initiative and its evaluation are synthetised in the vade-mecum, there is not enough space here to sum them up. They deal with the operational dimensions (moderating process,  involvement of resource persons, etc.), but also the wider issues (legitimacy of such processes, their role in public decision making and democracy, etc.).
column60: Walloon regional Ministry of Spatial Planning, Walloon regional Ministry of Mobility

column1: Citizens' Dialogues During the Royal Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada
column7: Citizens' Dialogues During the Royal Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada
column8: As part of it's public inquiry into the health care system, the Royal Commission conducted a 12-session, nation-wide "Citizens' Dialogue on the Future of Health Care in Canada". Insights and responses from the public influenced the final report's recommendations.
column17: Canada (Bathurst, Montreal, Québec City, Ottawa, Toronto, Thunder Bay, Calgary, Regina, Vancouver)
column18: The Commission on the Future of Health Care in Canada, the Canadian Policy Research Networks (CPRN), and Viewpoint Learning (a polling company).
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26: Randomly selected citizens contacted via phone survey
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column45: Web-based consultation (10,000 participants), public opinion telephone survey (1,600 respondents)
column46:
Participants expressed strong support for the public health system's continuing to provide "universal coverage" and "equal access."
Participants preferred to increase public funding for the public health system and to reorganize the primary care system, rather than creating a parallel private health care system.
Participants were willing to pay higher taxes for the public health system, provided that the system operate with greater efficiency, transparency, and accountability. Participants supported appointment of a health system auditor and a health system ombusperson to improve accountability and responsiveness.
If higher taxes proved insufficient participants were willing to accept user fees or copayments to fund the system.
Participants expressed a willingness to use new information technologies and to adopt preventative health and wellness measures to lower costs and increase the efficiency of the public health care system.
column49: Implementation of a few recommendations (less than 50%)
column56: Some have argued that Indigenous Peoples were insufficiently represented among Citizens' Dialogue participants and that, because Indigenous Peoples have unique health care issues, their specific circumstances and concerns were not addressed during the Citizens' Dialogue.
column60: Funded by the Government of Canada

column8: To  give feedback on Albany City's Council request to relocate the Albany administration building approximately 1.4 km from the centre of Albany's Central Business District. column26: The Jury was selected through a process of random sampling. The WA Electoral Commission provided a random sample of 600 residents living in the Albany region. Invitations from the Minister were sent to the 600 strong sample, asking them to participate in a Citizens' Jury on the selection of the site for the Albany administration centre. Of those, 92 responded positively, and a further random sample was carried out to select the final 17 jurors. However, there were no jurors under the age of 25. This is probably because the steering group eventually decided to have a random rather than random stratified sample.

They also suggested improving public transportation in both areas as well as introducing CItizens Juries more often in the policy making process
column57: Some citizens were unhappy with the final decision and had less trust in it as anonymous individual scoring of options was used to make the final choice.

In Beernem, 375 letters are sent but this only delivers an insufficient number of volunteers, so that an appeal to all the inhabitants is launched in order to reach the target of 12 participants; in the end, 10 people show up on the said day.
column33: Academics,Civil Society Organisations,Private Companies,Public Officials,Citizens,Public independant institution
column34:
Presented their views to the panelist citizens. 
The selection of these resource persons was made by the citizens, from a list proposed by an independent Composition committee. Despite the diverse list in terms of range of issues and positions, panelist citizens also asked for, and received, extra profiles to be added to the initial list (e.g. a philosopher).
column37: Outreach was ensured through: Public event for the disclosure of the citizens report. Media coverage. Dissemination of results. Later, dissemination of a publication that includes the citizens report, the detailed process but also all contributions by involved resource persons, to a wide range of decision-makers and stakeholders.

column45: There were a number of interactions between the Composition committee (CC) and panelist citizens. First, focus evenings are organised. The transcripts of the focus evenings structured by themes are sent to the citizens and to the CC, which will have the task to propose resource persons in relation to these themes. Project evenings follow. Citizens establish questions, requests and proposals of resource persons to be invited.Finally, organisation evenings take place. Based on the proposals of the CC, citizens set the agenda for the 1st panel day.
column46: A collective and consensual citizens report, later presented to the Federal Minister for Consumer Protection, Public Health and the Environment, the responsible Federal Public Service for Public Health, Safety of the Food Chain and the Environment, the general secretariat of the Biosafety Advisory Board (CCB), the Flemish Minister for the Environment and the municipal authorities of Beernem. On the Walloon side, neither the municipal authorities of Gembloux nor the Walloon Minister for the Environment were interested in receiving this opinion.
column54: Participant exit survey,Process reflection by the organisers
column56: Real struggle to involve citizens: two waves of mails were necessary in the first panel to recruit enough participants, and even there only 7 out of 12 citizens participate; in the second panel, a call to all inhabitants is launched in order to reach the objective of 12 participants.
column57: Lessons learned from the initiative and description of the process are synthetised in the final publication. The panel has been described as a rare place of respectful dialogue, among citizens and experts but also among experts, on a controversial and often conflictual topic.

column1: Consensus conference on genetic data

To discuss policy issues
related to genetic data.
column26:
Invitations were sent to a random
selection of 4000 people, 105 of whom submitted letters of application. From these, 12
people were finally selected according to demographic criteria
column37:
Public and media attention for the event was very poor. Apart from observers with a
professional interest and participants immediately involved, only interested visitors attended
the press conference. Just as small was the event’s resonance in the mass media, the ORF
was the only media group to take any real interest in the conference. Highlights included a
story in the ORF late news and a background report in an ORF radio program. Also, the
ORF Internet platform for science news, involved in the broad information campaign on
science and technology, covered the event with four reports and two commentaries. Much
feebler was media reporting beyond the ORF. The private print media corporations took
little notice. Online research resulted in five articles in three daily newspapers and about an
equal number in more specialized journals
column43: Learning sessions,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column57:
As all evidence demonstrates, political decision-makers never took notice of the event.
While the citizens’ recommendations had been passed to parliament with much fanfare, the
issue was never discussed or even mentioned in parliamentary deliberations. Nor were
administrative policymakers ever systematically confronted with the results of the deliberative exercise. Furthermore, at that time, there were virtually no legislative projects upon
which the consensus conference could have had any effect.
column60: Budget of the Austrian Council—Rat fur Forschung und Technologieentwicklung

column1: Scarborough Beach Deliberative Survey
column8: Following considerable local opposition to the proposed redevelopment of the Scarborough Beach precinct in Perth, a deliberative survey was conducted to understand if the community's views would be more united following deliberation.
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26:
Participants were randomly selected through a telephone survey where they were asked if they were willing to participate. To reduce bias people were initally not told that the area in question was Scarborough Beach. The sample was taken from three catchment areas: 60% from the area immediately near the Beach, 30% from a larger surrounding area, and 10% from metropolitian Perth. Participants were able to choose to either just do the survey or the survey and forum. The survey was then mailed to all people who agreed providing that they fitted with gender, age and area requirements.  A total of 453 people (61% response rate) filled in the first survey.

Initially, around 200 people agreed to attend the forum as well. However, on the day only around 100 people were able to attend.
column34: Contributed presentations
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Learning sessions
column45: A broader community survey
column46: Following the deliberative forum, the surveys showed that there was more support for high-density living options in the area. There was also increased recognition that substantial development was needed in the area to enhance it in order to attract people to live in the area. However, opposition to high-rises did not decrease. Therefore the Minister endorsed the development of residential blocks no higher than 8 stories. The results were also used to feed into the Metropolitan Coastal Strategy.
column60: Budget of the WA government department of planning and infrastructure (DPI)
column65: As the forum did not require a collective decision or consensus, the focus of the day was on learning rather than decision-making.

column1: Citizens’ Jury on Community Engagement and Deliberative Democracy
column7: Citizens’ Jury on Community Engagement and Deliberative Democracy
column8: Run as a demostration project. The jury evaluated a number of democratic methods, discussed how these methods might be used, and how citizens could be engaged in water management.
column26:
The jurors were recruited by random intercept recruiting in two locations - the Perth
central business district and Fremantle. Potential jurors were given a brief synopsis
of the project, and asked if they would like to hear more information about the project. Those who expressed an interest were
given a confirmation pack, which included more detailed information and also a
nomination form to complete and return. All people who were given a confirmation
pack were phoned by the recruiters 24 hours later to confirm their interest, and were
required to complete and return the nomination form if they wished to participate. Soft quotas were used for age, gender, education and political inclination to ensure a
representative and balanced final group. These quotas were used in the actual
recruiting, but more specifically applied when determining the final composition of the
selected jurors and alternates from the total pool of nominees. A selected group of
16 jurors and 4 alternates was selected to match the specified quotas. The final jury
comprised 13 of the originally selected jurors and 3 of the alternates.
column43: Reading material between meetings,Participants can request information,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column45:
In conjunction with the Innovations in Community
Engagement Conference
column46: Developed 10 key recommendations regarding the use of community engagement methods in Western Australia
column55: can be found within the report
column57:
As noted above in the comments on project limitations, staff feared that the use of a
Citizens’ Jury to study and consider a number of deliberative methods would lead to
strong support for the Citizens’ Jury process over other methods. In fact, none of the
three groups recommended the Citizens’ Jury process per se as a way to deal with
significant problems. Faced with the challenge of deciding how best to deal with the
issue of water in Western Australia, the jurors did not choose the Citizens’ Jury
process, but decided to invent larger methods that they thought would be equal to the
task.
column60: Budget of the Department for Planning and Infrastructure Government of Western Australia
column65: Interestingly, citizens came up with two deliberative democracy models of their own

regard to gender, area of residence, age, education

column1: Deliberative poll in Zeguo township, China
column7: Deliberative poll in Zeguo township, China
column8: To consider was which of a set of thirty possible infrastructure projects should be funded in the coming year.
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26:
A simple random sample of 275
Zeguo residents was drawn from a household registration list. Of the 275, 269 completed the
initial questionnaire, and 257 showed up on the day. Of the latter, 235 also completed
the final questionnaire
column46:
The participants became more interested in sewage treatment and road
construction that would affect their daily lives. All three sewage treatment projects received much
higher support after deliberation. The average support for Wenchang Main
Avenue, a new road that would cross a number of villages, increased by almost a full point. In
contrast, roads more specific to particular villages received diminished support. When it came to
parks, a ‘People’s Park’, for recreation, gained support, but Wenchang Park, a kind of town square
that was touted as good for the city’s image, lost support, as did commercial roads designed to
connect factories with main roads.
column57: There were too far too many men. This resulted from a failure to implement one customary element of Deliberative (and other careful) Polling, namely random selection within the household.
column65: The Zeguo Town leadership made – and carried through on – an explicit commitment to fund the projects the sample rated highest after deliberating. Therefore, this deliberation was effectively binding. The results were a decisive input into the policy process. All twelve of the projects the participants ranked highest after deliberating have been built. None of the projects they ranked lower has been.

column8: The European Citizens ’Panel on the Future of Rural Areas in Europe initiative aims to respond to agricultural crises by including citizens directly in discussions relating to the future of policies related to rural and agricultural regions. To this extent, one panel was organized in Wallonia. It is one of the eight regional citizens' panels intended to serve as a basis for the reflections of the European citizens' panel (composed of representatives of the eight regional panels, including two cross-border panels).
column26: Invitations were sent on behalf of the Minister of Agriculture, Rurality, Environment and Tourism. Random draw of 5,000 telephone numbers belonging to people residing in Wallonia. Out of 255 positive responses, 77 of them confirm their participation. A final selection retains 40 panelists, to achieve diversity in terms of age, gender, professional status and environment (urban or rural).

column1: The Netherlands’ Electoral System Civic Forum (Burgerforum)
column7: The Netherlands’ Electoral System Civic Forum (Burgerforum)
column8:
To investigate various electoral systems for choosing members of the Parliament, and eventually to
decide which system would be most appropriate for the Netherlands.
column26:
comprised of 143 individuals, drawn from a group of 1732 who self-selected
themselves from a random pool of 50,400 invited eligible voters
column43: Learning sessions
column45:
Public consultation phase, which involved
eighteen local meetings
column46:
In the system
ultimately recommended, voters would cast one vote, either for a specific
candidate from one of the party lists (as currently) or for a party list. Under the
proposal, citizen preferences would exert increased influence over which list
candidates get elected, since votes for specific individuals would garner more
weight than they currently do. The assembly also proposed a revision to the
method by which residual seats are allocated.
The Burgerforum’s set of recommendations was not presented to the population
in a binding referendum. Rather, it was submitted to a new government, elected
while the assembly was working. On 18 April 2008, the State Secretary of the
Interior and Kingdom Relations sent a letter to parliament, stating that the government would not implement the proposal of the citizen assembly.

ensured that individuals with asthma, coronary and pulmonary obstructive diseases were
included, as previous research had found these groups to have specific concerns with
regard to air quality, which were important to include.

column1: European Citizen’s Panel on the roles of rural areas (European + regional panels)
column7: European Citizen’s Panel on the roles of rural areas in tomorrow’s Europe
column8:
1 European Citizens's Panel followed 8 Regional Citizens' Panels in 6 languages and 10 regions over 9 countries (2 regional panels being cross-border), on theme of the future of rural areas in Europe.

Process took place from 2006-2007.
column9: Yes: 1) At European level: Steering Committee (oversight of the whole partnership and process at European level) + Methodology Comittee (set up and guarantees the procedural quality of the panels: method and independence) +  Sounding board (editorial board for the European infopack, a document providing outlining key challenges for the rural areas in Europe, shared with the panelist citizens before the European deliberations); 2) At regional level: mostly Monitoring Committees with regional organisers/deliberation expert practitioners and representatives of public commissioning bodies.
column11: Design and facilitation,Oversight,Ensuring balanced information,Providing expert knowledge
column17: Europe (EU Committee of the Regions, Brussels) + 10 regions: Bavaria (Germany), Durham (NE England) and Cumbria (NW England) counties (UK), Flevoland (The Netherlands), Cross-border panel in Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland (UK), Cross-border panel in Hungary and Slovakia, Rhône-Alpes (France), St-Gallen Canton (Switzerland), Wallonia (Belgium)
column18: European level: Foundation for Future Generations (producer) and AEIDL (coordinator); Regional level: International Institute for Environment and Development (United Kingdom), University of Newcastle (United Kingdom), Right 2B Heard (United Kingdom), Gesellschaft für Bürgergutachten (Society for Citizens Reports, Germany), Université de Liège (Belgium), Tr@me (Belgium), Free University of Amsterdam (The Netherlands), North South Rural Voice (Ireland and Northern Ireland), Queen's University (Northern Ireland - UK) and Economie & Humanisme (France)
column20: Independant public benefit foundation (European producer) + universities, consultant practitioners and specialised nonprofits (regional panels)
column26: 337 participants deliberated in the regional citizens' panel. They were randomly selected to fit a number of socio-demographic criteria. Among them, 87 delegate citizens took part to the European deliberations.
column28: Minister,Head of public institution,Specific govt department,Parliament
column34: Provide the citizens with their perspectives in the most accessible manner possible during sessions which are often open to the public.
column37: Outreach was ensured through: Public event for the launch of the initiative in the EU Committee of the Regions; Public event at regional and European levels (at the EU Committe of the Regions) for the disclosure of the citizens report and discussion with public decision-makers. Media coverage. Dissemination of results to a variety of stakeholders. Later, dissemination of a publication that includes the citizens report, the detailed process but also all other contributions from citizens, experts, evaluators at regional and European levels (in a DVD enclosed in the brochure). Website in 6 languages (www.citizenspanel.eu, now deprecated). A book was written in French (https://www.eclm.fr/livre/chronique-d-une-conference-de-citoyens/).
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column45: Before the final european deliberation, 8 regional citizens' panel were organized (including 2 cross-border panels, covering 10 regions in 9 countries).
column46:
On 2 April 2007, on completion of their discussions,
the panellists issued 24 recommendations, accompanied by their concerns and their visions for rural territories in Europe, addressing these to high representatives of the principal European institutions.
column56: There were numerous operational challenges: budget, logistics, wide theme, working in 6 languages, building a very wide partnership. But one of the main challenges was to find a listening ear among (especially European) public authorities. However, following upon this initiative, EU Commission DG Education and Culture (one of the funders) set up a budget line to organise (smaller) citizens' panels across Europe on themes linked to its competences.
column57: The regional and European Opinions, original and reasoned, clarify the priorities and the points of view of previously informed citizens. They can be seen as complementing reports from administrations, experts and stakeholders, and the opinion polls, on questions usually left to the experts alone. It is a particularly appropriate tool for complex and controversial questions.

column1: Citizens' Assembly on Electoral Reform (Ontario)
column8: To review the first past the post electoral system currently in use to elect members of the Ontario Legislature, with the authority to recommend an alternative
column26:
Selected
at random by Elections Ontario from the Permanent Register of Electors for Ontario.
Every registered voter was eligible to participate (with a few exceptions, such as
elected officials). Citizens that received an invitation letter were asked if they would be interested in placing their name in the draw. Of the approximately 12,000 respondents, about 1,200 were invited to attend selection meetings across the province.

At each selection meeting, candidates decided whether to put their names into a ballot box from which one member and two alternates were selected.
column43: Learning sessions,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Reading material between meetings,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column45:
Students' assembly held in parallel on the same question. 41 public meetings across the province, an invitation to make
written submissions, and special outreach sessions organized by the Social Planning
Network of Ontario on behalf of the Assembly. In addition, many Assembly members
undertook outreach in their own communities. Altogether, about 3,000 people shared
their views with the Assembly
column46:
The Citizens’ Assembly on Electoral Reform recommended
a new way to vote that builds on the province’s traditions
and reflects the values that are important to
Ontarians: to adopt
a Mixed Member Proportional system. The Assembly's recommendation was voted upon by Ontario voters in the referendum held on October 10, 2007, at the same time as the provincial election. The proposal was rejected by 63% of voters, meaning the status quo will stand in Ontario for now.
column60: Budget of the Ontario Provincial Government

column1: Citizens' Jury on the National Pandemic Response System
column7: Citizens' Jury on the National Pandemic Response System
column8: To provide opinions on the existing South Korea's National Pandemic Response System
column26:
Randomly extracted 135,000 phone numbers, and
successfully contacted 5,500. Of them, 118 expressed willingness to participate in the citizens'
jury. The 118 were grouped by demographic characteristics, and a final list of 59 was sent to the
project management team. The team randomly selected 16 candidates out of this list.
column46: Provided their opinions on questions like Korea's readiness to address pandemics.
column57: The deliberative poll faced criticism from both sides. The nuclear industry objected to the poll council’s adding a question about the future direction of Korea’s energy mix when the original survey asked only about specific projects. Environmentalists complained that pro-nuclear groups had more resources to make their case, including a strong network of government officials and academies, such as the Korea Atomic Energy Research Institute (one of the largest research institutes in the country). Others thought that the deliberation time was too short and the process for selecting topics was poorly defined.
column60: Budget of Center for Democracy in Science and Technology (CDST)

column1: New Mexico Citizen Conferences on Transportation

column18: The University of New Mexico Institute for Public Policy (IPP)
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26:
A pool of survey respondents was created for each conference by combining lists of people who
were reached during previous IPP surveys using random-digit dialing within New Mexico. These
pools were used to create approximate demographic quotas for each of the six conference areas
(e.g., for a given conference representing a particular region of New Mexico, 30-45% of citizen
advisors ought to be Hispanic). When interviewers recruited potential citizen advisors by phone,
they were careful to stay within these quotas.
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column46: In all of the Citizen Conferences the recommendations included thoughts on roads and road infrastructure, and specific roadways; alternative modes; safety; process, outreach and education; and funding considerations.
column60: Budget of the New Mexico Department of Transportation
column65: The 2007/2008 New Mexico Citizen Conferences' recommendations were "incorporated into the Goals and Objectives of the 2030 Plan in the locations noted, with slight modifications if needed to address the Department’s ability to actualize them, considering cost/benefits, available funding and staffing levels. Project overseen by J. Gastil.

column1: Edmonton Citizen Panel
column8: The goal was to gather informed citizen opinion on budget priorities for City Council as input into the subsequent year’s budget process.
column18: Jointly funded and organized by the University of Alberta and the City of Edmonton
column25: A mix of random and targeted selection
column26: Participants were selected by both random selection (for about two-thirds of the Panel) and targeted recruitment through outreach (for the remaining one third). Stratified on age, gender, income, minority groups.
column37: Online streaming of  some of the deliberations
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Reading material between meetings
column46:
The Panel recommended that City Council:

Continue to increase the density of our city through long-term planning.
Ensure that our transportation system emphasizes the convenience of users and the uniqueness of Edmonton’s climate.
Use environmental and economic sustainability as the basis for policy decisions aimed at livability.
Use proactive and preventive methods to reduce crime and increase safety, such as early intervention and gender-specific safety initiatives.
Additionally, the Citizen Panel recommended two “new directions” for City Council to pursue. First, the Panel called for a change in thinking to enable citizens to learn and flourish by changing incentives as Edmonton improved transit and increased density. Second, the Panel called for action that strengthens community life and engagement between citizens and elected Representatives.
column52: By the City of Edmonton local administration
column60: Jointly funded and organized by the University of Alberta and the City of Edmonton

column1: Deliberative poll on Transit and Traffic Issues in La Plata, Argentina
column7: Deliberative poll on Transit and Traffic Issues in La Plata, Argentina
column8: To discuss the transit and traffic issues facing the people of La Plata
column26: Close to 1,500 randomly selected people were surveyed and on October 31st, 62 participants joined policy experts and the Mayor for a full-day of deliberation.
column46:
The deliberations produced a number of large, statistically significant changes of opinion. Before
deliberation 71% of the participants agreed strongly that “creating bike lanes would increase traffic
accidents.” After deliberation this position dropped twenty points to 50%. Similarly before deliberation,
74% agreed strongly that “creating bus lanes would increase traffic accidents.” After deliberation this
position dropped nearly thirty points to only 45%. Before deliberation 54% opposed increasing the cost of
metered parking during peak hours. After deliberation this position dropped fifteen points to only 39%.
column55: Over 80 percent of participants felt the overall process, small group discussions, and large group discussions were valuable.
column57:
The participants also dramatically changed their view about whether public officials would listen
to their views. Before deliberation 60% disagreed strongly with the statement that “public officials care a
lot about what people like me think.” After deliberation this position dropped forty points to only 20%.
column60: Budget of the la Plata municipality
column65: In partnership with James S. Fishkin and Center for Deliberative Democracy

column1: WWViews on Global Warming
column8:
To deliberate about the core issues at stake in
the December 2009 UN negotiations on climate change.
column25: A mix of random and targeted selection
column26:
With regards to WWViews, the process has been the following for the National partners:
1.	Find national statistics for the distributions of their population by socio-demographic criteria: age, gender, occupation, education, geographical spread, membership of green NGO
2.	Make a recruitment strategy and discuss it with DBT (us). These strategies include:
a.	Sending out invitation to randomly selected addresses and choosing participants from a pool of applicants
b.	Hiring marketing bureau to find 100 participants that fit with the criteria
c.	Sending invitations through different community based organisations with national outreach (e.g in some African countries)
d.	Asking group moderators to find X number of profiles (e.g in Indonesia)
e.	Snowballing method
f.	And more
column43: Reading material between meetings
column46: Series of votes
column60: Donations from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs of Denmark, the Norwegian Ministry of Foreign Affairs and DNV (Det Norske Veriats, Norway)

column8: En 2011 Missions Publiques a accompagné Amiens métropole pour un atelier citoyen réunissant 19 habitants tirés au sort dans le cadre de la révision du Plan de Déplacements Urbains 2012-2020 de l’agglomération. Durant trois sessions de deux jours, comprenant des temps de formation et d’interactions avec des intervenants,  les participants ont travaillé à la production d’un diagnostic partagé et à la formulation de recommandations pour les acteurs publics. Par ailleurs, avant l’atelier chaque participant avait reçu un « carnet de bord », visant à compiler chacun de leurs déplacements, les facilités et les difficultés, voire même de réaliser un photo-reportage, avant de rendre la thématique concrète et de les aider à se mettre en situation de contributeurs actifs.

column1: Deliberative poll on the Press Law in Macao
column7: Deliberative poll on the Press Law in Macao
column8: To evaluate the proposed amendment  of  the Press  Law  and  the Audio-Visual  Broadcasting Act. Two deliberation panels: one of citizens and one of media experts.
column26: From  the  2,036  local  residents  successfully  interviewed  in  the  initial  telephone survey,  another  random  sample  was  drawn,  out  of  which  320  respondents  accepted our invitation to participate in discussions on DP-Day. Of the 67 people in the media professional group who filled in valid questionnaires, 30 accepted the invitation. The number  of  people  who  actually  showed  up  on  DP-Day  was  277  and  29  respectively
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column45: Surveys, call for proposals
column46: After deliberation, both the Press Law and the Audio-Visual Broadcasting Act require  amendment and the Journalists’ Code of Ethics require drafting.  As a result, this report recommends that the relevant departments ought to draft  new  or  amend  existing  relevant  laws  while  at  least  maintaining  the current level of press freedom and freedom of speech.
column65: In partnership with James S. Fishkin and Center for Deliberative Democracy

column1: Deliberative poll on Korean Reunification
column8: To discuss various aspects of the Korean unification issue – the conditions, timing, and consequences of reunifying the two Koreas
column18: KBS and the Department of Communications and Institute for Peace and Unification Studies at Seoul National University (SNU)
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26: Participants were selected based on demographics from those who responded to an initial questionnaire sent to gauge interest. The organizers ensured that the gender ratio of participants reflected that of South Korea. They also achieved a level of geographic diversity by selecting an equal number of participants from the three metropolitan regions of Seoul, Gyunggi, and Inchon.
column37: Direct streaming of the deliberation, documentary made about it
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column46: Post-event opinions had shifted dramatically from their starting point. Many more participants felt that reunification was necessary (71.6% to 91.2%) and that it would bring benefits for South Korea (48.2% to 72.6%). 59.6% supported and 23.8% opposed reunification if it would hurt the economy. 78.2% agreed that South Korea should cover reunification costs, though opinion was split (32.6% opposing, 38.9% supporting) on the unification tax.
column55: Can be found in the outcome document
column56: The choice to broadcast the event on KBS raises many interesting questions. Did the participants feel constrained or perhaps consider their opinions more carefully before speaking because they knew they were being recorded? Did more people, or perhaps a certain sort of person, volunteer to take part in the Deliberative Poll because they knew that KBS was involved?
column57: Participants ended the event with extremely positive feelings. On a scale of 0 to 10, 92.2% rated the event overall at a 7 or above. Participants valued the small group discussions the most (94.8% rated at a 7 or above), followed by the expert Q&A sessions (84.2% rated at a 7 or above) and informal conversations with participants over the weekend (79% rated at a 7 or above).
column60: Funds of KBS (Korea’s public broadcasting network) and the Department of Communications and Institute for Peace and Unification Studies at Seoul National University (SNU)
column65: In partnership with James S. Fishkin and Center for Deliberative Democracy

column1: Atelier citoyen Plan de Déplacement Urbain Grenoble
column7: Atelier citoyen Plan de Déplacement Urbain Grenoble
column8: De 2010 à 2012, Missions Publiques a accompagné l’agglomération de Grenoble et son Syndicat Mixte des Transports en Commun (SMTC) dans l’élaboration de son Plan de Déplacements Urbains. Un premier atelier citoyen d’habitants tirés au sort s’est tenu en 2010, afin d’explorer le sujet de fournir des premières recommandations exprimant des attentes à partir de l’expertise d’usage des citoyens. Ces propositions ont été intégrées dans des scénarios qui ont été présentés en 2012 à un nouveau panel, composé pour moitié de personnes ayant déjà participé en 2010. Ces scénarios ont été critiqués et évalués collectivement par les citoyens afin d’aider le SMTC dans la finalisation et la présentation publique du PDU. A ces sessions citoyennes se sont également adjointes de 2011 à 2012 des séries de réunions publiques, les cafés du PDU,  des ateliers thématiques réunissant les acteurs socio-économiques (entreprises, conseils de développement, associations et syndicats) et un comité de sage composé d’experts issus pour moitié du territoire, que nous avons également animé. Nous avons animé un forum à la fin de l’année 2012 qui a consolidé et présenté publiquement toutes ces contributions au PDU.

column1: Citizens' Forum: Future needs cohesion - diversity creates opportunities
column7: Citizens' Forum: Future needs cohesion - diversity creates opportunities
column8:
The Citizens' Forum brought together 10,000 people from all over Germany to contribute their ideas for social cohesion. At events and in an online discussion lasting several weeks, detailed citizen programmes are developed at 25 locations by 400 participants each. The programmes were discussed with representatives from politics and society. In a further voting process, a nationwide citizens' programme was created out of the the 25 regional citizens' programmes and presented to the Federal President.
In the kick-off event, the participants defined in a deliberative process their topics,  which were intensively discussed in the online phase.
At the regional closing event, the citizens' programmes were discussed with local politicians.
At the nationwide closing event, representatives of the regional citizens' forums presented the nationwide citizens' programme to the Federal President.
column9: Joint working group of Bertelsmann Stiftung and Office of the Federal President
column26: 400 citizens per city, randomly selected according to age (4 different age groups), gender and educational level (divided up in three groups). All together 10 000 randomly selected participants.
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Reading material between meetings,Participants can request information
column46:
The proposals from the citizens' programmes were followed up in the regions.
In some regions, follow-up events to the Citizens' forum were offered.
Contact persons in the administration to individual Committee topics were named . Some regional administrations set up their own participation strategies following the forum.
Participants launched their own initiatives or discussion groups on the topics of the citizens' programmes.
Discussion with Federal President, all secretary generals of major political parties and various ministers.
column49: Specific response to participants about recommendations
column56:
Random selection to guarantee a diverse participants group
25 citizen forums to be held on the same day
Set up of and maintenance of online wikipedia style participation platform
column57:
Many people are interested in new forms of civic participation. If there is a concrete and interesting offer, they are willing to contribute their time and ideas.
The combination of face-to-face events and moderated online discussion is a successful process. Participants can get to know each other personally at the events and determine the first topics that will be discussed in the online discussion is very helpful.

column56:
Concerns expressed about the sampling procedure used in the citizens’ jury methodology,
and the capacity of the participating citizens to represent the views of the broader
‘uninformed’ community.  Most elected representatives did not appreciate the deliberative and educational
contribution of mini-publics. In particular there were misunderstandings about how the
process worked and at times the scientific language appeared to distract and be unhelpful. The broader democratic potential of mini-publics tends to be under-valued or underappreciated by elected representatives.
column57:
1. Elected officials are more supportive of mini-publics once they have had the
opportunity to observe and experience a deliberative process involving everyday citizens. 2. Mini-publics enable MPs to hear from a broader set of publics than they would
normally hear from, which is crucial when they are deliberating on policy issues of state or
national significance. 3. Successful mini-publics need a committed champion who can work closely with
the conveners, and communicate with any sceptical parties. 4. Independent and non-partisanship organisations, such as newDemocracy, play a
vital role in instigating and convening mini-publics, especially in highly politicised contexts. 5. To minimise confusion and misinterpretation, the use of scientific language
should be minimised when describing mini-publics, particularly when referring to the
selection process and the ‘representativeness’ of the participating citizens. 6. Effort should go into demonstrating that everyday citizens do care about complex
issues, and want to participate in their governance. 7. There is a need to understand further the resistance of MPs to devolving or
sharing power.

column26: An automated telephone survey of the general Edmonton population was undertaken to define baselines for the attitudinal questions in each demographic target. 1297 Edmontonians completed this general population survey. Prospective participants were contacted through an initial automated recruitment call to random Edmontonians (total contacted: 2397). Data was gathered using survey questions (demographic and attitudinal) with phone key responses; willingness and availability to take part were also recorded. Additional telephone follow-up was completed with a pool of those who provided telephone responses (total of 317). Final selection was completed to establish a Citizens’ Panel that was as representative as possible of interlocking demographic and attitudinal criteria. Sixty-six Panelists were invited to participate in the 2012 Citizens’ Panel.
column43: Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column46:
The Panel concluded that the City of Edmonton does indeed need to take active measures to become a low carbon city by 2050. They came out in support of the following six deliverables as proposed in the Discussion Paper:

“Reduce the greenhouse gas intensity of the provincial electricity grid”
“Increase the proportion of development undertaken to create compact, mixed-used, transit-oriented neighborhoods within already developed areas”
“Reduce energy use in industrial facilities through energy efficiency”
“Increase the uptake of distributed energy generation”
“Increase the energy efficiency of buildings”
“Reduce the amount of gasoline and diesel used in the vehicle fleet”
column57: Meanwhile, in any replication of this model in the future, the coordinator might consider more structured programming for gathering opinions outside the walls of the conference room through neighbor interviews assigned to each participant and/or a popular survey administered and publicized with the help of the participants. Additionally, media transparency in terms of the matters and topics discussed during the sessions did not occur until the program was over and the Final Report was presented; if possible, the coordinator might also consider allowing regular press coverage of the six sessions.

1.	Find national statistics for the distributions of their population by socio-demographic criteria: age, gender, occupation, education, geographical spread, membership of green NGO
2.	Make a recruitment strategy and discuss it with DBT (us). These strategies include:
a.	Sending out invitation to randomly selected addresses and choosing participants from a pool of applicants
b.	Hiring marketing bureau to find 100 participants that fit with the criteria
c.	Sending invitations through different community based organisations with national outreach (e.g in some African countries)
d.	Asking group moderators to find X number of profiles (e.g in Indonesia)
e.	Snowballing method
f.	And more

column1: Estonia's People's Assembly 'Rahvakogu' on Elections, Political Parties and Citizen Engagement
column7: Estonia's People's Assembly 'Rahvakogu' on Elections, Political Parties and Citizen Engagement
column8:
The Assembly focused specifically on five questions: the electoral system, political parties, competition between the political parties and their internal democracy, financing of the political parties, strengthening the role of civic society in politics between the elections, and stopping the politicization of public offices.
It was a multi-step process that lasted for four months:
1. first proposals were crowd sourced on the platform (using the Icelandic Citizen Foundations' freeware)
2. then the collected ideas were grouped and analysed by experts, and the structured recommendations were discussed and voted upon in thematic seminars
3.  18 proposals were discussed upon at the Deliberation Day where more than 300 randomly selected persons decided to present to the Parliament of Estonia 15 proposals.
column9: Yes, The planning and design of the Rahvakogu was coordinated by a group of civic organisations, analysts and democracy innovators. The planning meetings were open to journalists and party representatives.
column18: A range of NGO's and political parties
column19: the facilitating organisation was the Estonian Cooperation Assembly, www.kogu.ee
column25: Single stage random selection (e.g. polling company recruitment)
column26:
Organizers commissioned a public opinion polling company to organise the random sampling. The national population registry was used to randomly select 500 individuals according to the socio-demographic profile of Estonia. Of the 500 who were invited, 314 individuals took part in the ‘Deliberation Day’ event. This group broadly reflected the Estonia population in terms of age, ethnicity, occupation, and gender.

In the discussions preceding the Deliberation Day around 100 experts of civil society, political systems and elections took part.
column28: Other (please specify in participant selection methodology details)
column34: Co-designing the Rahvakogu process and the Deliberation Day, implementing everything, communicating about it.
column36: Rahvakogu.ee - a dedicated platform was created (not active any longer, materials are archived).
column37: Very actively, the national broadcast was the main partner that communicated every step during the four months, also live-streamed the Deliberation Day. Other media channels also reported on Rahvakogu actively.
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions
column45: Yes, online submissions to crowd source draft amendments and gather support to these recommendations was implemented as the first phase of Rahvakogu.
column46: 15 out of 18 discussed proposals were passed to the Estonian parliament, the Riigikogu, for legislative amendments. The President of Estonia handed the recommendations to the Parliament, along with a speech.
column52: The organisers of Rahvakogu are following the work of the Parliament within their everyday work.
column56:
1. Lack of post-communication of the results of the Rahvakogu: the voluntary coordinating team ran out of energy (with some people burning out) and thus the post-communication suffered. It created a false understanding in the Estonian society that Rahvakogu did not change anything. In following years some communication on the results and impact of the assembly was done, like updating this website:  https://rahvakogu.ee/peoples-assembly-in-2013/

2. The parliament of Estonia agreed to implement the modest recommendations, not the whole package of 15 recommendations.
column57:
1. The process design should incorporate post-assembly activities like monitoring the implementation and communicating the results.

2. Stronger collaboration needed with politicians, so that they would not regard the assembly as a parallel parliament (like it was done by many), but as a supplement to parliamentary work.
column60: Core funding for the project came from the Estonian Cooperation Assembly, a state sponsored nonpartisan think tank, while the organizational costs of the ‘Deliberation Day’ event were primarily covered by a grant from the Open Estonia Foundation. However, most of the work on the project has been done by volunteers.
column65:
According to the Estonian Cooperation Assembly, 3 out of the 15 proposals sent to the parliament were adopted into law while 4 have been partially implemented or integrated into the government's commitments.
Results are listed here: https://rahvakogu.ee/peoples-assembly-in-2013/

column8: How can society distribute the available budget in the fairest and most equitable way possible and what criteria should be taken into account for reimbursing medical care?
column26: From the National Institute of Sickness and Invalidity Insurance (INAMI) and the Federal Center of Expertise in Health Care (KCE) : initially, a survey aiming to find out the preferences of citizens in terms of reimbursement of health care was sent by the KCE to a panel of 20,000 Belgian citizens drawn by lot on the basis of the national register. Of the 4,810 people who took part in the survey, 100 expressed an interest in participating in the citizen panel. At the same time, additional profiles were recruited by iVox [method unclear], reaching a total of 175 volunteers. Secondly, a selection of 32 panelists (16 French-speaking and 16 Dutch-speaking) was made from among these volunteers, respecting diversity in terms of gender, age, language, residence and professional situation.

column1: Citizens' panel on aging - Our Future
column7: Our Future - Citizens in search of sustainable models for intergenerational solidarity
column8: Our Future - Citizens in search of sustainable models for intergenerational solidarity was a participatory initiative on the challenge of aging, involving a citizens' panel (2013-2014), as well as the production of key questions and scenarios by different group of experts as a first step (2012-2013).
column9: Yes. 1 Monitoring Committee (guarantees the procedural quality of the panels: method and independence) + 1 group of experts identifying key issues and challenges + 3 group of experts (2 existing, 1 assembled for the purpose of this initiative) who designed contrasting scenarios based on these key challenges.
column17: Citizens selected in all Belgian provinces. Meetings in Brussels, Blankenberge, Kortenberg, Wégimont
column25: A mix of random and targeted selection
column26: The panel of 24 citizens was recruited with a view to ensure maximal diversity. Part of the panel was selected using randomized lists. Another part was also randomly selected but on smaller lists through resource persons, with a more targeted approach. This method enabled to combine classic criteria (age, gender, language, socio-economic status of course) with other criteria important to maximise the perspectives on the issues at stake (number of children or dependant (grand)parents, housing, geographical dispersion, sociological dispersion, political affinities, well-being indicators, risk of precariousness, etc.).
column33: Public Officials,Academics,Private Companies,Civil Society Organisations,Public independant institution
column34: 1) Experts and stakeholders: brought key issues in the first step. 2) Independant academic and nonprofit think tanks: brought 3 contrasting scenarios in the second step. 3) Monitoring Committe: advised on the thematic issues and on the methodology.
column37: Outreach was ensured through: Public event when presenting the citizens report. Discussions with public and private decision-makers. Sending the report to commissioning public and private partners in advance of a public discussion. Writing of the citizens report in the form of a magazine. Translating citizens recommendations into stories. Media coverage. Dissemination of results to a variety of stakeholders.
column43: Introductory reading material before 1st meeting,Participants can request information,Learning sessions
column45: The key issues and 3 contrasting scenarios, also adapted into stories, were written materials presented to the panelist citizens at the beginning of the process. In addition, hearings were organised with number of expert and stakeholders.
column46: 1) In the form of a magazine, a publication with the final citizens report and information about the whole initiative and process, as well as some interesting interviews, analyses and first reactions. 2) 4 scenarios for the future (3 from think tanks, 1 from the citizens' panel), all converted as well into stories ('Me, Roland, 58 year old in 2030'). 3) Feedbacks from commissioning public and private partners.
column56: 1) While there are many documents on aging, its health/employment/retirement dimensions etc., there was little systemic thinking on the issue at stake integrating these dimensions in a prospective fashion. That is why scenarios were developed on this complex issue, to help bring a wide number of facts, trends, figures and analysis into sevarl contrasting, but coherent, visions of the future. 2) While the commissioning public and private partners were very interested into the citizens report and process, the underlying issues addressed by the panel are major and politically sensitive (pension system, health system, employment, solidarity, inequalities, etc.). The panel approached these issues in a creative and rather systemic way, integrating them in a global vision. The public decision-making system in Belgium has difficulty in dealing with these issues, and even more so in integrating them together. For example, the reform of the pension system is an issue with multiple consequences and is politically highly charged. Constantly postponed, its reform has not yet taken place, contrary to what was announced at the time of the panel, except for certain aspects (the retirement age was delayed in the next government).
column57: The report, scenarios, process and lessons learned from the initiative are presented in a magazine-like publication. The panel approached the theme in a creative and systemic way, integrating many key issues together (employment, retirement, health system, intergenerational solidarity, quality of life for the elderly, etc.) and that is quite rare.
column60: A mix of public and private funding (for-profit company, nonprofit foundations)

column26:
With regards to WWViews, the process has been the following for the National partners:
1.	Find national statistics for the distributions of their population by socio-demographic criteria: age, gender, occupation, education, geographical spread, membership of green NGO
2.	Make a recruitment strategy and discuss it with DBT (us). These strategies include:
a.	Sending out invitation to randomly selected addresses and choosing participants from a pool of applicants
b.	Hiring marketing bureau to find 100 participants that fit with the criteria
c.	Sending invitations through different community based organisations with national outreach (e.g in some African countries)
d.	Asking group moderators to find X number of profiles (e.g in Indonesia)
e.	Snowballing method
f.	And more

column1: Sharing the Roads Safely: Citizens Jury
column7: Sharing the Roads Safely: Citizens Jury
column8: In South Australia’s second Citizens’ Jury 37 everyday South Australians were charged with finding innovative ideas as to what could be trialled so that all road users could share the roads safely.
column26:
Recruitment was conducted by newDemocracy Foundation.
Members of the Jury were randomly selected through an independent non-partisan research organisation, the newDemocracy Foundation.

The selection of jurors is deliberately independent from government and aims to ensure the jury is representative of the broader South Australian population. Invitations to participate in this Citizens' Jury were sent out to a randomly selected sample of over 6,000 South Australians drawn from an Australia Post address database, and from those that indicated interest a stratified random selection was conducted which simply matched the group to the Census profile by age, gender and housing status (ratepayer/ tenant) as this has proven effective in getting a diverse mix of people in terms of income and educational background. newDemocracy has noted in previous processes that other factors of our identity such as self identified ethnic background, being indigenous, LGBTIQ status and disability are selected in proportion to the size of these populations within the community.

column45: Supporting by online submissions and YourSay
column46: The Jury made a range of recommendations - with the majority being supported by government and put into law.

column1: City of Melbourne: Future Melbourne
column8:
The Future Melbourne 2026 citizens’ jury deliberated over a matter of public significance.  Their outputs would help to shape the development of a long term, strategic plan that would guide the council over the next decade.  This significant task included ensuring that the plan represented the needs and aspirations of a diverse community and a large, complex city.

Following the wider engagement phase, the jury deliberated online for more than three weeks, and met in person over three and a half days.
column26: The jury was selected from the respondents to the over 7,000 invitations sent to people who live, work or own a business in the municipality. These were randomly distributed invitations.
column43: Reading material between meetings,Participants can request information,Experts available at meetings for presentations and/or questions,Introductory reading material before 1st meeting
column44: Surveys (online/offline),Call for submissions/proposals,Citizens' forums,Online discussion forums
column45:
Yes - Phase one was the ideas phase. This was an open invitation for individuals, groups and organisations to share their ideas for the future of Melbourne. Over two months, 2000 people engaged in this phase through over 30 face-to-face events and 2000 engaged in online conversations to produce 970 ideas and complete 350 surveys for the future.
In phase two, the synthesis phase, these ideas were analysed and then synthesised as a commentary on each of the Future Melbourne 2008 vision and goals.
Finally, phase three was the deliberative phase.
column46: The Future Melbourne 2026 Citizens’ Jury agreed on 9 Goals and 54 Priorities and in August 2016 the Future Melbourne Ambassadors (six leaders from the Melbourne community) commended Future Melbourne 2026 to Council.
column49: Public response to recommendations,Specific response to participants about recommendations

column57:

column1: WWViews on Climate and Energy
column8:
To gather citizen views on international climate
change and energy policy issues and disseminate them to policymakers involved in the UNFCCC

column18: Co-initiated by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC) secretariat, the Danish Board of Technology Foundation (DBT), Missions Publiques (MP), and the French National Commission for Public Debate (CNDP), with the support of the French Government host of COP21.
column25: A mix of random and targeted selection
column26:
With regards to WWViews, the process has been the following for the National partners:
1.	Find national statistics for the distributions of their population by socio-demographic criteria: age, gender, occupation, education, geographical spread, membership of green NGO
2.	Make a recruitment strategy and discuss it with DBT (us). These strategies include:
a.	Sending out invitation to randomly selected addresses and choosing participants from a pool of applicants
b.	Hiring marketing bureau to find 100 participants that fit with the criteria
c.	Sending invitations through different community based organisations with national outreach (e.g in some African countries)
d.	Asking group moderators to find X number of profiles (e.g in Indonesia)
e.	Snowballing method
f.	And more
column43: Reading material between meetings
column46: Series of votes
column60: Some partners were self-financed but several partners, especially from developing countries benefited greatly from the financial support of Ségolène Royal, the French Minister of Ecology, Sustainable Development and Energy, which providing financial support to 61 countries.

column1: Nuclear Fuel Cycle Citizens' Jury
column8: To determine whether South Australia should continue to pursue opportunities connected to the Nuclear Fuel Cycle.
column26:
25,000 invitations were sent to randomly selected
addresses across the state using an Australia Post
database.  Of 1121 who responded, a jury of 52 was randomly selected to align with
census data for age, gender and geographical location.
column37: Use of regional and national media
column45: Two stage Jury process. Jury 1 (54 citizens) analysed the Nuclear Fuel Cycle’s Royal Commission Report and highlighted the issues that need to be discussed and resolved in the community. Jury 2 (350 citizens) considered “Under what circumstances (if any) could South Australia pursue the opportunity to store and dispose of nuclear waste from other countries?” Also, online and in-person feedback, as well as a community survey and parliamentary inquiry were conducted.
column46: Produced a range of recommendations related to nuclear waste management. Overall rejected the government proposal to accept nuclear waste from other countries to be disposed in Australia.
column56: The unusual size of the jury caused tension; the jury was under strong time pressure. This resulted in distrust of the deliberation process.
column57: 1. On polarised topics, deliberative processes can be of more use exploring the details and nuances of people’s positions, and considering the conditions and contingencies that political decision-makers must meet in making a decision. 2. 350 citizens for a jury is arguably too many to successfully manage the process.
column60: Budget of Government of South Australia

column1: A cable car for the citizens of Wuppertal?
column7: A cable car for the citizens of Wuppertal?
column8:
The Wuppertal suspension railway is well known in Germany. To further improve accessibility, the city considered a cable car that would connect the city centre in the valley with a school and the University Campus on the hillside. The idea was to overcome the demanding topography of the city.
The project was controversial, as the cable car would run over inhabited areas. Therefore, the mayor decided to involve citizens in decision making using the method of Planning Cells.
column45: Public informational events and discussions with stakeholders.
column46: Panelists listed arguments for and against the cable car, and concluded recommending to conduct a thorough cost-benefit analysis and funding options.
column57: The results show two things: On the one hand, the participants regarded the event as neutral and fair. On the other hand, there is a high degree of satisfaction with the content and the course of the event. Each individual citizen reviewer fully recommends participation in such a procedure.
column60: Budget of the council of Wuppertal

column1: Citizens' forum on pensions in Baden-Württemberg
column8: Deal with a controversial political issue at the state level: the adequacy of the pension scheme for members of the state parliament. In 2008 it was decided that the parliamentarians would henceforth be given the maximum lump sum for the statutory pension insurance of around 1,500 euros (today: 1,720 euros) for building up private old-age insurance. This was changed again in a shortened parliamentary procedure. After considerable public criticism, the state parliament of Baden-Württemberg withdrew this decision - it remained with the private, subsidized old-age provision. Based on the recommendations of an expert group that had been advised by the citizens' foru, it changed the system to a Pensions Fund.
column26:
The company “Bamberger Center for Empirical Studies” ( https://www.uni-bamberg.de/zentren/baces/ ) commissioned with the random selection of the participants used two different samples. The first, significantly larger, sample consisted of randomly generated landline connections according to the Gabler-Häder method, which was provided by GESIS - Leibniz Institute for Social Sciences in Mannheim. The second sample consisted of private individuals' mobile phone numbers listed in the Baden-Württemberg telephone directory.
 
The total of 26 067 telephone numbers from both samples were called by the BACES interviewers with the support of a computer-assisted telephone system. If a person was reached by phone, the employee of the recruiting company introduced himself as an employee of BACES and as a contractor of the Independent Commission of the State Parliament of Baden-Württemberg and explained the key data of the project in terms of both content and organization.
 
If the person called expressed interest in the Citizens 'Forum, he was sent a cover letter containing the essential information about the Citizens' Forum (e.g. background of the Citizens 'Forum, the core of the proposed and canceled changes to the pension scheme for MPs at the beginning of 2017, place and time of the Citizens' Forum , Travel expenses and daily allowance) as well as a registration form with the request for a binding registration. 
 
BACES collected these registrations and evaluated them according to the specified quotas (age, gender, administrative district). If a registration fit into the open quotas, the person received a confirmation of participation, otherwise they were informed that they would be placed on a waiting list. In this way, BACES ultimately selected 27 participants from the four administrative districts and with different socio-demographic characteristics.

First, random digit dialing was used to
create a pool of almost 4,000 interested Canadians.
Second, final participants were selected from this pool
to reflect the diversity of Canadians at large. Primary
demographic selection criteria included gender, age,
family income, education, Aboriginal identity and
visible minority status. Several secondary demographic
selection criteria were considered to reduce
participation bias, including participants’ employment
status, the presence of children under 25 years of age
in participants’ households and whether participants
voted in the last election.
Attitudinal diversity was matched to a baseline
public opinion poll.  190 participants
for the regional dialogues. 35 invited to attend the pan-Canadian
dialogue in Winnipeg. Participant selection on geographic, demographic
and attitudinal characteristics to ensure that citizens
reflected the diversity of Canadians at large as closely
as possible.
